reviewText:
Is this a joke? The description of the game is longer the actual game.

All you do is seriously drive around one track for as long as you can without any obstacles other than the occasional roadblock with a ramp and a gunship that spawns every 8 minutes getting in the way. That's it. That's the whole game. The bullets don't even do anything! They're not even a threat! All they do is make the road randomly spawn debris in your face which comes with no warning. There's no other hazards... just hard turns, roadblocks and a gunship. Pitiful.

The only good thing this game has going for it is a nice aesthetic and some pretty good music. $3 for literally 8 minutes of gameplay... 13 if you actually can make one full lap without falling asleep. Literally get the ♥♥♥♥ out.

Perhaps I'm being harsh on, say, a college student's final project for school but this isn't something you charge people for. Nitronic Rush was a final project for school and that had more content and was released free. This is a 99 cent mobile game AT BEST. Also, don't copy Powerdrive 2000. You're not Powerdrive 2000. And you're not going to ride off it's kickstarter success.

If you want a game with more in-depth gameplay and content check out Distance (the same team who made Nitronic Rush).

reviewText: As the game is now, I cannot recommend it. The gamepad support is broken. You need the boost ability, but it doesn't work with a gamepad. The drift is also pretty bad. The game has an interesting idea (keep up the speed or your girl dies), a simple but nice art style, and dynamic, speed-dependent music - but the controls eliminate every bit of enjoyment you might have gotten out of it. If they work on this, it might turn out to be a decent game in the future, though. I will give it another try at some point.

reviewText:
Oh OutDrive where did it all go wrong ?

I wanted to like this game I really did, but man it's not worth it, so let's get into it.

In OutDrive you play as the Driver. His girlfriend is shot and you hook her up to your Delorean and you have to maintain a certain speed to keep her alive.Drive too slow she dies, drive too fast she dies.

The neon visuals and overall the entire design is fantastic, but sadly that's where the good ends and the bad begins.

The game is endless and there's no ending what so ever, and to experience everything the map has takes you at least 15 minutes and after that there's nothing else. There are obstacles in the road like road blocks and ramps. There are also random encounters like traffic and a helicopter which shoots at you, but it does absolutely nothing and after a few shots the helicopter explodes.

The entire game gets tiring after a few minutes and after that there's nothing to do.

The soundtrack is great and is really fun to drive around to listen to the music, but it's not worth to play the game just to listen to the music.

I wanted to like this game, I really did, but I can't, my honest recommendation is to wait until Powerdrive 2000 comes out this coming May,

Final Rating:
3/10 - Don't Bother

reviewText:
Outrun and its sequels are arcade classics. This is a series that's all about driving all over the world in an expensive sports car. It's just you, the road, and the love of your life. Even when you're not behind the wheel of a Ferrari, your car has the top down, so both the driver and the passenger are visible. This is a minor detail, but it really adds to the sense of escapism. In Outrun 2, the girlfriend is very expressive, cheering on your successful driving skills, and getting annoyed when you bump into cars. While it's easy to say that the Outrun games are great, due to their fantastic controls and solid game-design, it's the tone and atmosphere that really bring it all together.

Outdrive is...well I'm going to be serious here. Outdrive is a twisted metaphor for keeping a loved-one on life-support. In the intro, your girlfriend is shot during a hired hit, a drug deal gone bad, or actually... nevermind. The reason is irrelevant. Basically, she's going to die, and there's nothing you can do about it. Even knowing this, you hook her up to your car's engine to keep her alive. This isn't a temporary measure; you aren't going to get her to the hospital or anything. The purpose of this game is to drive for as long as possible, until you either go too slow, too fast, or realize the futility of it all and pull the plug.

I hate to go on a moral tangent in a videogame review, but I'm just calling it like I see it. After hooking your girlfriend up to your car, the only signs of life she exhibits are open eyes and in-between songs you can hear some breathing. Granted, she was mortally wounded only minutes ago, but she's already in what could be considered a vegetative state. It would be different if she spoke, or showed some awareness. Maybe she would talk about what happened, use her last moments to reflect upon better times, etc. It's not like her condition will improve, so why do this? So the two of you can sit in silence and listen to synth-music while looking at the neon li-everything?

Oh right, the game portion, I nearly forgot to talk about this. In short, the controls are awful. As the other reviews have stated, keyboard-only is the way to go, because you have to constantly boost to keep the girl alive. For whatever reason, the gamepad doesn't function properly. Steering is problematic, and drifting sends you into just as many walls as not-drifting. Oddly enough, your speed doesn't actually matter. As long as you have your finger on the boost, and are making at least some forward (and sometimes even backward!) progress, then the girl will stay alive". It's entirely possible to drive at 10-15 mph and it wouldn't affect anything. After about eight and a half minutes

reviewText:
GNARLY GAME -- and not in a good way.

You can only play OutDrive using keyboard controls, which are overly sensitive, so your car turns 90 degrees into a wall if you're not very, very careful. Maintaining control of the car is difficult given how keys have been mapped -- very cramped. You can re-map the controls, but this kind of game really needs controller support. In this day and age, for this type of game, not including PROPER controller support is just lazy.

And for those of you that say that you CAN use a controller ... well, it is not working properly for me. For example, when using the boost, which you absolutely need for this game, I can see it's working, but the game doesn't seem to recognize it, so I die anyway.

To survive, you must keep your speed within a certain band -- you can't drive too slow or too fast for extended periods or game over. I can understand a mechanism that encourages the player not to go too slow, but too fast is a problem ...? Totally lame mechanism.

Final verdict: 1/10 - Not rad. The 1 point is for style and graphics, but lack of substance.I was hoping for an OutRun-like game ... simplistic but enjoyable driving, but OutDrive is not fun at all. Don't be swayed by the cool graphics, which are definitely amazing. But the game itself is boring and frustrating, with terrible controls. Classic case of a game that have some interesting ideas and looks gorgeous, but fails in execution and gameplay. OutDrive does not deserve your money when so many better games are out there.

reviewText:
FULL DISCLOSUREI paid nothing for this. It was a giveaway thing. As such the following will be written from that perspective.

Outdrive is a game that is almost not a game. It has some loose narrative in that your girlfriend gets shot and you must 'out drive' the the 'bad dudes' in order to save her and presumably get her to a hospital, if such a thing even exists in the retro neon dystopia of the far flung future. The juxtaposition here is that there is no hospital. For what seems a procedurally generated track, the actual game is really just an endurance run with a timer.

You must use boost to keep the car at speed designated by the blue bar directly behind the car. Go to fast or go to slow. She dies.

Now, the music in this game is actually quite decent. Its mindless and very relaxing. The tempo decreases and gets distorted when your car is not going at speed. Which is a bit disappointing for relaxing aspect of it but its no matter really.

I had a hell of time trying to get a gamepad to actually do anything worth while. Trying two 3rd party programs as well as just setting the key bindings in the setup utility. I eventually settled on just WASD'ing my way through it. I'm no stickler for peoples preferred control method but certain genres beg a specific control scheme. Either way WASD works well enough for this task.

The car physics are extremely suspect as well. A gentle tap on the wall will send you spinning and usually end up facing the other way. It seems once the car leaves the ground it weighs less than a piece of paper. At one point I started driving sideways on the invisible boundary of the track and a helicopter knocked me off and I was able to drive out of bounds a short while until I was blasted into the sky and juggled for a bit until my girlfriend died.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=669195383

All in all, for free I can't complain. The music is good and WASD isn't totally the worst thing ever for an arcade driver. However, I would never recommend this should you have to pay for it.

I'll start this review by saying that OutDrive is at best a glorified flash game.If this ''product'' would have been released in the 1980's,it would have been a decent experience but it was released on Steam in 2016.

ControlsDefault controls for keyboard are WASD for directions,SHIFT for speed boost and SPACE for drifting.

GameplayIf you jump into the game without reading something about it beforehand,you might be confused.The game fails to explain exactly what the objective is.Apparently you need to save the girl by driving fast.If you are driving too slow,her heart will stop.If you are driving too fast,it will hurt her.Sounds simple enough..and it is.After 5 minutes you will be bored to death.The music isn't particularly good for you to keep playing..and you can simply listen to it online and do something else in the meantime.Only one map that never ends and after awhile,seems to repeat itself.No obstacles,weird car physics and an attack helicopter that spawns and shoots you even if you are in a tunnel but misses every single shot all the time.

GraphicsThe retro style graphics look decent and the world around the car is certainly more interesting than the gameplay.

MusicIt's nothing special and every track sounds familiar because it's the stereotypical retro music that you already know too well.And if you don't,you can find better retro music elsewhere and you can certainly find better things to do while listening to it.

OutDriveI can't recommend this game for a few reasons.First of all,it has a pricetag.There are literally thousands of free games out there that are better than this.Second of all,there are literally thousands of similar/better retro music tracks out there that don't require you to play a boring car game.

''Not a game,aesthetic concept'' This quote is taken from the description of the game.But it has a pricetag.If it's a aestethic concept,make it free.Don't bother with this.

reviewText:
OutDrive is almost a great experience (ALMOST). The aesthetic is of course top tier and the music is great as always new age synth. In this respect it feels like FarCry: Blood Dragon mixed with the movie Drive and that is a stylistic match made in heaven. These music and visuals are both pretty solid qualities of the game but unfortunately what supports these aspects are nowhere near as impressive.

You simply drive in OutDrive, it's a procedurally generated driving game in which you just have to keep moving within a certain speed range or else you fail. Sometimes there's some random events that happen but that literally just consists of either brief oncoming traffic or an attack helicopter that tries to shoot you. These are handled pretty well for the most part and I don't mind a game in which you just drive but there is a real lack of content here, even for a game that's £2.

There are no online leader boards or particular diversity to each playthrough. Despite technically driving through a unique path each time, it barely feels any different and having only a couple of short random events just leaves me slightly unsatisfied.

However there are two major problems with the game that render the rest unimportant. The game performs horrendously, this will likely be one of the most demanding indie games you play. It's surprising how good of a rig you will need in order to run this game at 60FPS, it even struggles to maintain 30FPS on a PC that can run most big releases on mid-low settings. Another problem in terms of optimization is crashes, I've had this game crash 4 times on me completely out of nowhere and I've heard similar complaints from other Steam users.

The second major problem would be the controls, the car just doesn't handle well at all. It feels rigid and clunky, I fail to see how such a key aspect of a driving game was made so poorly. While it's possible to overcome the bad car handling to an extent, you'll never feel as though it plays the way it should.

I really wanted to like this game and from a visual and audio standpoint I absolutely do. I even think many tracks from the OST will be ones I'll listen to outside of the game. But a lack of diversity, lack of real content, lack of optimization and lack of decent controls stop me from being able to recommend this game. Don't bother with the game at all, even if you see it for free just don't get it.

Scores:

Audio & music : 8/10
Visuals: 8/10
Gameplay: 3/10
Optimisation & performance: 2/10
Value (at full price): 5/10

Final verdict: 4/10 AVOID COMPLETELY!!!

reviewText:
Product received for free

Tl:DR: It looks great, sounds great, but is held back by mechanical weakness.

Story:
Outdrive is a game about driving (unsuprisingly). The story outlines a nameless man who gets in trouble with some other nameless men, leading to the first mans girl getting shot and now the only thing he can do to save her is hook her heart up to the engine and keep on driving so she can keep on living. Essentially, the story is very week and should not really be bothered with.

Sound:
The music in this game is fantastic, no other way to put it. It really helps bring out the neon 80's aesthetic and doesn't get old too fast. The sound effects are serviceable but are nothing special and the acceleration effect can become irritating after awhile.

Graphics:
Another thing the game does well is visually present itself. It looks great and the color scheme is perfect for the atmosphere the devs were shooting for. As a side note the launcher itself could have a few more presets. Even though it's a unity game it would be nice to have 8x AA without forcing vsync on as well.

Controls:
The controls in OutDrive aren't terrible but they don't necessarily feel good. The steering feels rigid and the drifting can be quite fiddly at times, which many times ends up with you smashing into the invisible barriers alongside the road.

Gameplay:
This is my major gripe with this game. Now, first let me clarify that I understand that the devs were not trying to develop a game" persay
date: more of an "experiment" or "aesthetic concept" as the description puts it. That being said
recommended: that doesn't excuse OutDrive from having a mechanic that really irritates me and that really is a shame because funnily enough
hoursPlayed:
it's one of the only mechanics in the game. The mechanic in question is the fact that you have to balance out your speed so that your girls heart (which is hooked up to the motor) doesn't overheat or get damaged. On paper this sounds like an excellent idea and I can kind of see where they were going with it. However it means that you can never buildup speed and you must constantly slow down to make sure that your girl doesn't die and end the game. There is also almost no obstacles anywhere and even cornering is ridculously easy due to the slow speed you are forced to move at. This one gripe could be easily be fixed by either eliminating this mechanic all together or just creating a seperate mode where you could drive as fast as you like (hoping the devs add this in the future!).

Conclusion:
I'm going to recommend this even though I don't beleive it's worth the full $3 CAD. For 99 cents I'd pick it up

reviewText:
First of all, i'll ignore Power Drive 2000 in this review,
because while similar in the 80s style, i think there's a place for both games.

But to OutDrive itself:
In general i like the game.
The Story is simple but enough for this game: Drive fast so that the girl survives.
The 80s style design is really nice and the music is fitting and good.

One neutral point is the potential time you can get out of the game.
I don't think i'll play it more that 1 hour in it's current form.
But at the same time, 1,60€ for 1 hour of entertainment is ok in my eyes.
Maybe future updates will bring new content

But there are also numerous issues:
The steering just isn't very good, a very short tap left/right and the car will change it's direction way too quickly.
Maybe alter it a bit so that a short keypress will initial change the direction only slightly while increasing the rate over longer key presses.

Another big issue is bugs, mostly clipping:
My first run lasted 9 minutes, at which point the helicopter created an explosion while i was on a ramp and suddenly i was below the road, falling until the girl had died.
On my second run nearly the opposite happened, a helicopter explosion boosted me about 20m above the road where i was able to keep driving and only fell down back to the road at some point 1 minute later (i think there was a ramp on the road at that spot..)

TL;DR: I think the game delivers enough gametime for it's price, so i'll give a positive (slightly above neutral) recommendation.

reviewText:
Possibly the only endless runner game I'll ever play. Despite the controversy around the game that seems to be brewing in the community, the game itself is a pretty relaxing affair with some very stylised and fitting 80's inspired synth-heavy music. Visuals are great and hypnotic and it's pretty nice to just phase out and take it all in. However, the game does play like a poor man's, bare bones Distance. If you're looking for complexity in a racing game such as this, you wont find it here. The gameplay is very limited and would probably bore most gamers after 10 or so minutes.

However, I have fallen oddly in love with the game. It's very much an audio/visual experience than it is a video game. Choosing style and [dare I say] aesthetics taking into consideration before gameplay, depth, and plot.

Game would be a lot better if the controller setting were a little more optimised, as using the WASD keys and SPACE to drift around counters does feel a little clunky. Would feel much more smoother and a little more versatile on a controller. I'm pretty sure most of the keys are mapped, but I find that the boost button is off, patch that and I'll be happy.

reviewText:
OutDrive is an aesthetically beautiful game, with an atmospheric soundtrack that will pull you into the game albeit the game's mechanics need lots of work. Keeping up with the speed you're supposed to drive at isn't tough but it is awfully distracting when you bump into walls and the soundtrack slows down.

The best part about this game is the audio, and to punish the player by pulling them out of the amazing soundtrack they were listening to only because they drifted incorrectly is a terrible mechanic. If they can rework that single problem, I wouldn't mind holding my WASD/space keys down for an hour on this neon lit road towards the neon sun. OutDrive doesn't have controller support  yet, and the game's resolution is a bit hard to get right. I hope that the developers intend to fix this soon because I would love to play this game often.
